bboxes.raw_text:
The first Negro county super
visors of the Farmers Home Ad-
ministration have achieved out
standing records in providing
sound credit services and guild
ance for farmers in nine Cali
fornia counties, the u S. Depart
ment of Agriculture agency re-
ports.


Supervisors are Paul R. Conn,
a graduate of Tennessee A. andI.
State University. and Lowell A.
Pannell, who holds a MASTER
degree from Prairie View,
Texas, A. and M. College.


Conn, headquartered at San
Diego, serves San Diego and
Imperial Counties where he made
ll9 loans lastyear, totaling more
than $1,000, 900, to white, Jap
anese, and Filipino fruit and veg
etable growers. he says there
are practically no Negro farmers
in the area. Repayments during
1868 totaled about $425, 900.


Loans we're for annual oper-
ating expenses, the purchase or
enlargement of family farms, the
construction or repair of homes,
development of water supply sys-
tens, conservation of soil, and
for emergency needs resulting
from unfavorable weather or
floods. Farmers Home loans are
available to farmers who are un-
able to obtain satisfactory credit
elsewhere.


Mr.. Conn joined the agency in
1860. After a training period,
he was assigned to county in
northern California and later
transferred to San Diego.


The 3l-year-old supervisor

The National Council of Negro
Women. Inc. was organized in
1885 by Mary Mcleod Bethune;
picture left. In twenty-five af-
filiated organizations, NCNW
represents three million women.


NCNW is a council through
which IS national organizations
speak, work, plan and act to-
gether. 1t brings together women
who belong to religious,
fraternal, business. profess
sional, civic and social organiza-
lions.


The head of each national Or
ganization belongs to the Board
of Directors of NCNW. And
each affiliate head appoints a
liaison to represent her group
in Joint planning at NCNW national
headquarters Washington, DC.


The national President is Miss
Dorothy 1. Height of New York
City, pictured right.


The current program ofNCNW
includes: Maintaing observer

was born and reared on a to-


bacco and strawberry farm near


Franklin, KY, where he was


All er and a member of the
New Farmers of America organ
ization. After four years, 1882
So, in the Air Force, he entered
Tennessee A. and |. and ma jored
in agricultural economics. He is
married and has an 8-year-old
daughter.


Pannell, who has been with
Farmers Home since 1855, has
his headquarters in San Jose and
serves farmers in Alameda,
Monterey, San Benito, Santa
Clara, Santa Cruz, San Fran
cisco, and San Mateo Counties
which are rapidly being indus
trialized.


Working intensively with the
borrowers, many Of whom have
part-time jobs in town, Mr.. Pan
nell has succeeded in helping
them improve some Of their OPP
creations, become more soundly
established as farmers, and en-
nance their credit standing. "Our
goal is to graduate the borrowers
from our rolls and take on others
in need of our services" says
the 39-year-old supervisor.


In addition to servicing the
borrowers, most of whom are
either white or Japanese truck,
dairy, or livestock farmers, Mr..
Pannell also helps train newly
appointed supervisory personnel
of Farmers Home.


His skill in agricultural credit
has made him a popular speak
err before San Jose business
groups, including the Rotary Club
of which he is a member.

z Negro County
Farm Supervisors In California

status at the United Nations. is
affiliated with the National Coun-
ell of Women of the United States,
the International Council of
Women and the Pan Pacific and
Southeast Asia Women's As
ISOLATION.


Sponsoring leadership training
conferences for women


Promoting responsible voter
registration and voter education


Providing a mobile family
health service clinic for migrant
workers and their families at
Frederick, Maryland with a grant
from the United States Public
Health Service and professional
leadership of the Howard Uni
versity School of Medicine.


Responding to the challenge of
the President Conmittee on the
Status of Women.


1t provides scholarships for
43 students working in nonviolent
civil rights movements.

An old chenille bedspread or
bathrobe can be converted into an
excellent buster for ceilings, walls,
and holdings.


Cut out two rectangles, stitch
up three sides, and run a draw
string around the opening so that
it will fit snugly over a broom.
After each use, be sure to launder
this "slipcover" buster in hot soap
or detergent suds and rinses.

CHICAGO = Charles R. Walton.
Al yr. old Negro, apparently
committed suicide after brooding
over the mysterious disappear
ance of the three civil rights
workers in Mississippi.


\ Police found ~ caliber re-
volver in the front seat of the
dead mans car which was parked
on the Calumet freeway.


One of the five notes on the
seat read: "This is for the three
in Philadelphia. They wouldn't
let me join the movement and I'm
giving my brain this way"

Mon Kills


Self Over
Missing Trio
